meanings.definition: To leave property to someone in a will.
meanings.sent1: My grandfather decided to bequeath his antique watch to me in his will.
meanings.sent2: She chose to bequeath her entire estate to charity.
meanings.sent3: In his will, he humorously bequeathed his collection of rubber ducks to his best friend.
meanings.sent4: The old tree seemed to bequeath its wisdom to the young saplings growing around it.
meanings.sent5: The ancient king's final act was to bequeath his kingdom to his loyal subjects.

meanings.definition: To pass something on to someone else.
meanings.sent1: The teacher decided to bequeath her knowledge to her students before retiring.
meanings.sent2: He wanted to bequeath his father's legacy of kindness to his own children.
meanings.sent3: The magician jokingly bequeathed his disappearing trick to his mischievous cat.
meanings.sent4: The setting sun seemed to bequeath its warmth to the cool evening breeze.
meanings.sent5: The wise elder bequeathed her stories to the eager young listeners.
